articles.content:
# The Celebrated Chef Who Robbed Banks

Published: 2025-11-09T05:00:49-05:00

On a warm May morning in 2018, a man with a graying beard sidled into a Citibank in Orinda, a suburb in Northern California. He was over six feet tall and burly, but it was the way he was dressed that stood out. Black hoodie, sunglasses, latex gloves. And he carried a duffel bag.

“I knew exactly what he was doing,” recalled Kamyar Amintaheri, a manager of the bank at the time. “I told my banker to hit the alarm — we’re getting robbed.”

When the man approached, he was visibly shaking as he held up what would later be identified as a BB gun. Mr. Amintaheri assured him that a teller would cooperate. “I said, ‘It’s OK, hold the gun at me,’ and I talked him through it. You could tell he was nervous.”

The man made off with about $18,000, driving away in a 1997 black Mercedes. The authorities managed to track him down that same day.

His name was Valentino Luchin. He was 54 years old and a resident of nearby Lafayette.

He was also an acclaimed chef.

The news shocked many in the Bay Area. Mr. Luchin had once been the executive chef at the famed Rose Pistola in San Francisco. His own restaurant, Ottavio, had delighted critics and patrons with its soulful Italian food.

Mr. Luchin eventually pleaded guilty to one count of second-degree robbery and served six months in a county jail, during which he worked in the kitchen.

After he was released, he seemed to blend back into the restaurant scene.

Until this past September, when Mr. Luchin, at 62 years old, was accused of robbing three more banks.

Born in the Venice area of northern Italy, Mr. Luchin began working at age 15. He apprenticed with a chef, studying the region’s cuisine, and was praised for his natural abilities.

In the early 1990s, he relocated to New York and learned English while working at the popular Italian restaurant Becco.

After several jobs in the Seattle region, Mr. Luchin went on to oversee restaurants at luxury hotels in Orlando, Fla., and Hawaii, including the Grand Hyatt Kauai Resort & Spa.

“He’s revamped the menu, with dishes such as handcrafted black-ink lasagna,” announced Honolulu Magazine.

In 2007, Mr. Luchin landed the prestigious post at Rose Pistola, a storied institution that championed dishes from Liguria and had been credited with helping change the landscape of Italian food in America.

Mr. Luchin’s technique and deep knowledge of food were exciting. The way he added liver to his Bolognese sauce and simmered it for hours, or how he steamed his risotto to concentrate the flavors.

“Little things like that made me admire him,” said Pablo Estrada, who worked as his sous-chef and now runs his own restaurant. “I got along with him because I understood his philosophy. But not everybody felt that way.”

Former staff members said that Mr. Luchin could exhibit an ego and clash with colleagues. They recalled that he also might have had trouble managing the food and labor costs. Less than a year passed before he was fired.

Soon after, an acquaintance introduced Mr. Luchin to Kenneth Maraccini, a businessman who owned a metallurgical laboratory and was intrigued by the idea of opening a restaurant. A partnership was born. Mr. Maraccini fronted the money. Mr. Luchin dreamed up the menu.

By then Mr. Luchin was married, with two children. His wife, Michele, would help with the venture.

In the spring of 2010, they opened the doors to Ottavio.

Ottavio’s northern Italian fare was a welcome addition to the quaint downtown of Walnut Creek, an affluent and bustling suburb just east of Oakland.

The restaurant itself was modest, its tiny vine-covered exterior easy to miss. Inside, the walls were a deep purple, and candles flickered on about a dozen wooden tables. The staff was spare, and servers were responsible for making drinks and sometimes busing dishes.

But Ottavio became a local gem, praised for its fresh pappardelle with wild boar sugo and its pork chop with fig-apricot mostarda — a triumph in a region known for its competitive restaurant scene.

Diablo Magazine raved: “Small but mighty, Ottavio wows with details not often spotted outside of Italy. Crisply fried sage leaves, a Piave cheese that’s been aged to a heavenly nuttiness, and almost everything — the pasta, the cured meats, the smoked fish — made in-house: This is labor-of-love cooking.”

The star of Ottavio was Mr. Luchin. “Is Valentino in?” was the frequent query of guests, who could also order a citrusy vodka cocktail named in his honor.

Often described as a bear of a man, Mr. Luchin would emerge from the open kitchen, his curly hair mussed and cheeks ruddy, to chat up guests, most of whom were charmed by his thick Italian accent.

In January 2013, Mr. Luchin and his wife signed a deal to take over full ownership of the restaurant, agreeing to pay Mr. Maraccini $100,000 over five years.

But Ottavio had already begun to face what would become an array of financial and legal issues. A supplier had sued for nonpayment of delivered goods, and two former employees had filed claims with the state’s Labor Commissioner’s Office for unpaid wages and tips.

One claim resulted in an award of $74,000. To recoup some of the debt, a court-appointed receiver ordered the couple to turn over the restaurant’s liquor license, which he estimated could be sold for up to $17,000.

Shortly afterward, the Luchins stopped making payments to Mr. Maraccini.

At one point, Mr. Luchin reached out to two loyal customers, Claudia and Todd Holloway, and asked for a few thousand dollars to pay his employees.

“He said, ‘I would understand if you cannot do it, but I’m desperate, so I need to ask,’” Ms. Holloway said. Although they turned him down, the couple said Mr. Luchin remained just as friendly toward them.

In the fall of 2015, the Luchins filed for Chapter 13 bankruptcy, listing their debt at more than $111,000.

According to court documents, the restaurant had pulled in $355,000 over the previous 12 months, but the couple’s salary was about $73,000, considered low-income for the area. Sometimes Mr. Luchin would wait on tables himself just to earn tips. The case was dismissed after the Luchins were unable to make required payments to creditors.

Guests began to sense that something was amiss.

Chantal Rees was dining at the restaurant in July 2016 when Mr. Luchin spoke of his need for more customers. He insisted on showing her the room where he cured his meats.

“He was really grasping at anything,” Ms. Rees said. “It was almost like he was drowning.”

A few months later, Ottavio quietly closed.

There is a facade to fine dining that belies its eternal struggles. No matter how costly the wine, how crisp the tablecloth, how attentive the server, someone behind the scenes is striving to contain the myriad costs.

Entrees that Yelp reviewers dismiss as overpriced pay for the employees’ salaries, the flatware, the electricity, the heat, the insurance and, oh yes, the food itself. Margins are razor-thin.

Which is why many in the restaurant industry may not condone robbing a bank, but can understand the depth of desperation that would lead one to do so.

“If you knew this guy, you would absolutely be heartbroken — clearly, the stress wore him out, and he made terrible decisions,” said Jim Telford, who owned a wine bar around the corner from Ottavio.

Mr. Telford said he and Mr. Luchin would commiserate on the difficulties that came with getting their businesses off the ground. But he was often surprised by the generosity of the chef, who made gestures like delivering elaborate meals when Mr. Telford’s daughter celebrated her first birthday.

Once, when players with the Golden State Warriors were dining at Ottavio, Mr. Telford ordered an expensive bottle of wine to be sent to their table.

“I tried to pay for it, and Luchin was like ‘No, no, no, that’s on my dime,’” Mr. Telford recalled.

In early 2018, Mr. Luchin inquired about a job with Mr. Telford, who had opened a restaurant. The only available position was for a sous-chef. Mr. Luchin declined. Soon after, he robbed his first bank.

Following his time in jail, Mr. Luchin took a job in San Francisco at Doppio Zero, an Italian eatery with multiple locations.

“We thought we’d give him a chance,” said Gianni Chiloiro, one of the restaurant’s owners, about Mr. Luchin. “He’s mellow — he’s not a violent criminal with a temper. He just screwed up.”

The crime was well known among staff members and became somewhat of a joke. One afternoon, Mr. Luchin took a break and said he was headed to the bank.

“And everybody said, ‘No, no, don’t go to the bank!’” Mr. Chiloiro recalled. “He laughed and said, ‘I have to go deposit my check.’”

On the last day of 2019, Mr. Luchin filed a petition for Chapter 7 bankruptcy.

According to court documents, Mr. Luchin’s annual income was $75,000, about one-third of which went toward helping his children. He owed more than $97,000 — most of it appearing to stem from the deal to buy Ottavio and the accrued interest. He was also indebted to multiple food vendors. In addition, another former Ottavio employee had won a judgment of more than $134,000 for back wages.

After a couple of years, Mr. Luchin left Doppio Zero. He surfaced in 2022 at the Old Clam House, an area establishment that had reopened under new ownership.

In an SFGate article, Mr. Luchin was referred to as the restaurant’s chef who would add some Italian dishes to the menu. There was no mention of his criminal record.

On Sept. 10 this year, in the middle of the day, three banks within two blocks of one another in downtown San Francisco reported similar events. In each, according to court transcripts, a man with the same physical description had passed an employee a note with a brief message.

This is a robbery.

The first occurrence was just before noon at CTBC Bank in the Chinatown neighborhood.

“Don’t worry,” the man said from behind a black mask. “Give me the money.”

He then hit up a BMO Bank and a Bank of America. At the latter, a teller recognized him as a recent customer who had tried unsuccessfully to cash a check.

The authorities quickly turned their attention to Mr. Luchin, who was staying at a nearby hostel. He was arrested that day and booked into a county jail.

Just a few months earlier, Mr. Luchin had been in touch with Bay Area acquaintances, reaching out for job opportunities. Among them was Michelle Salas, the manager of Spiazzo, a restaurant where Mr. Luchin had a brief stint years earlier.

“He was at his breaking point,” recalled Ms. Salas. “He was out of money, he needed to pay for his room, he needed to eat, he needed to just be able to get by.”

Business had been alarmingly slow across the region, but Ms. Salas tried to connect Mr. Luchin to possible jobs. His 2018 robbery had never bothered her. Ms. Salas’s own decades-long career in restaurants had been rife with anxiety and financial instability, along with family troubles.

“I get the stress behind it,” she said. “You reach a point where you just do crazy things.”

But when word spread that Mr. Luchin was once again accused of robbery, Ms. Salas wondered, “What the hell is he thinking?”

Mr. Luchin is housed in a correctional facility in San Bruno, 17 miles south of the scene of his latest crime.

Held on $200,000 bail, he wears an orange jumpsuit and sleeps on a bunk bed in a room filled with dozens of other inmates. Most refer to him as “Chef,” his heist having earned him some cred.

He is facing two counts of second-degree robbery and two counts of attempted second-degree robbery.

“I’m very stressed,” Mr. Luchin said during a recent phone call with The New York Times. “Sometimes I have the shivers, you know? I’m trying to keep it within. I think I’m doing pretty good. We’ll see how long it lasts.”

The bank robberies, he said, came after a long downward spiral.

He had moved to Maui two years ago for a promising job that ultimately fizzled, then had trouble finding steady work on the island. He was in two motorcycle accidents, sustaining injuries to his back, shoulder and head. Struggling with substance abuse and his mental health, he said he checked himself into rehab. He was later charged with shoplifting liquor from a grocery store — the owner of which told The Times that he had terrorized her employees. (“My mind wasn’t there,” Mr. Luchin said.)

Mr. Luchin filed for divorce last year. In court papers, he said he was earning less than $40,000 and could not pay alimony. Ms. Luchin said that she had been unable to find work and that Mr. Luchin had promised to pay for her rent. She had also requested a restraining order, saying her husband could be verbally abusive and prone to anger.

After returning to San Francisco earlier this year, Mr. Luchin’s latest venture was offering culinary classes and personal chef services, but he said someone had paid him with what turned out to be a fake check. The bank froze his account. In early September, he was threatened with eviction.

Just as in 2018, Mr. Luchin said he felt as if he had exhausted all other options. That’s when he approached the three banks. He said he made off with $3,000 and paid his weekly rent before the police appeared.

Mr. Luchin said he regretted his actions. “When you have a breakdown, you don’t really reason very well,” he said.

Hoping to be released on his own recognizance, he is painfully aware that he is destitute in the outside world. “Am I getting any remuneration for this?” he asked during a conversation with The Times. (The Times does not pay for interviews.)

For now, he spends his days doing thousands of crunches and practicing yoga, reading books on Roman history and mindfulness, waiting in line to make 15-minute phone calls to friends and his son.

He has also been thinking about a new restaurant concept.

“I want to hire former incarcerated to give the opportunity — if they are clean and sober — to re-establish their life,” he said. He imagines an Italian-Californian theme, along with some Asian fusion dishes. Perhaps beef cheeks with red curry, and a classic gnocchi with a smoked duck ragù.

To him, it is a viable image: “I’m notorious for standing back on my feet.”

Casualties do lie in his wake. There are the former employees of Ottavio who went without proper compensation, and the unpaid vendors. The bank employees who endured moments of fear.

There is also Linn Maraccini, the widow of Mr. Luchin’s onetime business partner. Ms. Maraccini, whose husband died in 2023, said her family was never fully paid what they were owed for the sale of Ottavio. Saddled with the findings of a tax audit for Ottavio, she also said they were forced to take out a reverse mortgage on their house.

“I could care less what happens to him,” Ms. Maraccini said of Mr. Luchin. “I am not vengeful, but he left us in a real pickle.”

She could not, however, deny his talent.

His food, she said, was fantastic.

articles.title: Josh Shapiro Knows What the Democrats Need
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article argues that Josh Shapiro, Pennsylvania’s governor, represents a viable and effective model for the Democratic Party to regain political ground in swing states. With a record of delivering tangible results — such as reopening a collapsed highway in 12 days and advancing economic development in Pittsburgh — Shapiro has become the most popular politician in Pennsylvania and outperformed other Democrats in rural and exurban areas. The piece contends that the Democratic Party must embrace centrist, pragmatic governance to win in key battleground states, especially given widespread public distrust of government. It cites examples from other centrist Democrats like Gretchen Whitmer and Andy Beshear, and contrasts Shapiro’s approach with the ideological rigidity of progressive candidates. The article also highlights how Shapiro’s policy mix — including support for school vouchers, public safety, infrastructure, and inclusive hiring — reflects a balance between traditional Democratic values and practical governance. His success, despite opposition from progressive factions, suggests that a renewed Democratic strategy must focus on proving that government can deliver results, thereby restoring public trust and enabling the party to regain power.

Shapiro's political strategy emphasizes action, transparency, and practical outcomes, such as reopening a collapsed highway in 12 days and investing in public safety and economic development in cities like Pittsburgh.

He combines bipartisan elements like supporting police funding, school vouchers, and a lower corporate tax rate with core Democratic values such as a higher minimum wage and support for public education.
Shapiro's popularity (60% approval rating) and his record of governing effectively suggest that centrist, results-driven politics can appeal to voters in key swing states like Pennsylvania.

The article argues that for the Democratic Party to reclaim power, it must embrace centrist, pragmatic politicians like Shapiro, as this approach addresses voter concerns about safety, infrastructure, and economic growth.
Shapiro's success challenges progressive Democrats who believe the party should remain ideologically pure, suggesting that effective governance requires compromise and practical policy solutions.

Shapiro’s political model is grounded in reforming institutions rather than destroying them, aligning with conservative thinkers like Edmund Burke who viewed stability and institutional continuity as essential for democracy.

articles.content:
# Josh Shapiro Knows What the Democrats Need

Published: 2025-11-09T06:00:05-05:00

This essay is the fourth installment in a series on the thinkers, upstarts and ideologues battling for control of the Democratic Party.

A cardboard cutout of a presidential candidate could win California on the Democratic line and another 15 deep blue states. The question Democrats need to answer, the question that matters for the future of the Democratic Party and quite possibly for the future of democracy in America, is what kind of Democrat can win Pennsylvania.

As it happens, we already know the answer. His name is Josh Shapiro.

In his last three elections, beginning in 2016, Pennsylvania’s governor has drawn more votes than anyone else running in the state — presidential candidates, Senate candidates, other candidates for statewide office — and outperformed other Democrats in the exurban and rural areas where the party is struggling.

Centrist Democrats govern several of the states that President Trump won in 2024, including Michigan’s Gretchen Whitmer, who won office on a promise to “fix the damn roads,” and Kentucky’s Andy Beshear, who has championed a bipartisan “Team Kentucky” approach to attracting corporate investment to the state.

Mr. Shapiro intrigues me because, in an era of widespread distrust in government, he has become the most popular politician in the nation’s most important battleground state by insisting that government can work.

He has a record of delivering clever political compromises, and he’s good at making centrism sound urgent. His political persona is a constant performance of vigor. As he reminds Pennsylvanians at every opportunity, he gets stuff done. His most celebrated achievement is reopening a collapsed highway in just 12 days.

Tuesday’s election results have supercharged the debate among Democrats about whether the road to political recovery runs toward the middle or the left. The reason the argument persists is not because the answer is unclear but because, for many Democrats, the clear answer is unpalatable. The party will not return to the White House, nor reclaim Congress, until it learns to embrace centrist politicians like Mr. Shapiro.

Zohran Mamdani’s victory in New York does not demonstrate the viability of progressive candidates outside of a few big cities and coastal states. Nor can Democrats solve their problems by wrapping the same ideas in better paper. The party has marginalized itself so thoroughly that even Mr. Trump’s unpopular presidency isn’t doing much to make Democrats more popular. Everything Democrats want to accomplish is downstream from figuring out how to persuade voters in places like Pennsylvania — and in a bunch of places where the Democratic brand is held in even lower regard — that the party deserves another chance.

Mr. Shapiro’s recipe is a plausible basis for the party’s renewal. Democrats are the party that believes in government; they have to show that government can work. They have to deliver the stuff they’ve already promised: education, security, opportunity.

As Pennsylvania’s attorney general in 2020, Mr. Shapiro repeatedly battled Mr. Trump’s legal assaults on the integrity of the state’s election results, delivering the kind of confrontations that many Democrats crave. But the way to beat Mr. Trump is to show Americans that you have a better alternative.

Mr. Shapiro’s version of the Democratic Party is more patriotic than the G.O.P. and, in some sense, more conservative. It is a party that wants to improve public institutions rather than blowing them to smithereens, and to carry forward the basic elements of the American experiment: liberal democracy, a pluralistic society, free markets regulated in the public interest.

History teaches that people will readily sacrifice democracy to regain a sense of safety and stability. Mr. Shapiro recognizes the urgency of convincing people that democracy is still the better bet.

One of the most durable patterns in American politics is that voters trust Republicans more than Democrats to fight crime and deliver economic growth. It’s no coincidence that on a recent Friday, Mr. Shapiro was in Pittsburgh to talk about crime and economic growth.

Standing on a bluff above the Allegheny River, he delivered a progress report on a package of investments in downtown Pittsburgh, which loomed photogenically behind him.

It was a surprisingly hot day, and much of the crowd had retreated under a canopy. Aides handed out water bottles to the municipal workers who had been rounded up to stand with Mr. Shapiro. The governor, dapper and trim, hair slicked back, grin like a Cheshire cat, didn’t seem to notice the heat. He looked as if he was having fun.

“These projects are moving fast,” Mr. Shapiro told the cameras. “We are not wasting any time.”

The Pittsburgh plan is a relatively modest intervention into the city’s fortunes, but it’s a good illustration of Mr. Shapiro’s political formula. The first rule of improvisational comedy is “yes, and ….” You accept what the last person said, and then you build on top of it. Mr. Shapiro takes a similar approach to forging political compromises. He’s in favor of more money for the police and for public defenders. He has pushed to increase funding for public schools and to provide school vouchers to parents. He has delivered some high-profile wins for businesses, notably a cut in the state’s corporate tax rate. He also has retained strong support from unions by backing a higher minimum wage and vowing to block any right-to-work legislation.

His Pittsburgh plan is a standard set of economic development and public safety proposals, with some distinctly Democratic touches: subsidies for the redevelopment of office buildings and housing for the homeless; more police officers working downtown and increased collaboration with social services agencies.

A second tenet of Mr. Shapiro’s approach is telling people, repeatedly, what he is doing to help them, and that he is doing it as fast as possible. In June 2023, a tanker truck caught fire underneath an elevated section of Interstate 95 in northeast Philadelphia, causing a portion of the highway to collapse. The road was expected to be closed for months, but Mr. Shapiro declared a state of emergency and approved a plan to fill the area underneath I-95, allowing rapid construction of a temporary replacement on top. He went before the cameras and promised to reopen the highway in two weeks. It reopened in 12 days.

Government often doesn’t work because the left cares more about procedures than outcomes, and the right opposes the outcomes. One side wants to start building a modern railroad between Los Angeles and San Francisco just as soon as all the paperwork is done; the other side wants to kill the project. Neither approach helps to move people between the cities.

Mr. Shapiro rejects both the proceduralism of the left and the nihilism of the right. In a recent conversation, he told me that he was “someone who believes the government can be a force for good in people’s lives.” A substantial majority of voters no longer trust government to pursue big projects, and Mr. Shapiro was quick to add that he understands and shares the frustration with government in its present shambolic condition. “Our institutions are important, but need to be reformed,” he said. “Our fundamental responsibility is to show our work and deliver for our people — to get stuff done.”

(Mr. Shapiro often uses a different word in place of “stuff.” He told me that he was censoring himself because he was talking to The Times.)

On his first day as governor in January 2023, Mr. Shapiro signed an executive order eliminating college degree requirements for most state jobs. It was an effort to help lower-income Pennsylvanians — and a corrective, he said, for his party’s elitist tendencies. “For the last more than a decade, the Democratic Party has been saying to people that you’re not really successful unless you go to college,” he said. “I think that’s offensive.”

The best case for Mr. Shapiro’s brand of politics is that it works. The last time he lost an election was in 1990, when he was an 11th grader at a high school outside Philadelphia and he finished third in the race for student body president.

After graduating from Georgetown Law and working on Capitol Hill, Mr. Shapiro returned to Pennsylvania in 2004 and won a seat in the state House. In 2012 he traded that job for a seat on the board of commissioners in Montgomery County, a Philadelphia suburb, and in 2016 he became the state’s attorney general. His defining chapter in that job was his defense of the integrity of the 2020 election. He repeatedly beat back the attempts by Mr. Trump’s campaign to make voting more difficult, and then to prevent the counting of votes that already had been cast. In 2022 Democrats regarded him as the obvious choice to run for Pennsylvania governor, and he won in a landslide.

Mr. Shapiro’s most immediate political challenge is running for re-election next year, but it may not be much of a challenge. Polls shows that he’s more popular today than when he was elected. His approval rating stood at 60 percent in a poll published last month by Quinnipiac University, with 28 percent disapproving.

When I asked Mr. Shapiro if he is interested in taking his brand of politics national, he demurred in the way that a practiced politician does when he is keeping his options open. “I’m humbled and flattered that you view the way in which we govern in Pennsylvania as a model for others,” he said.

There are some obvious reasons to worry about his national appeal. He is a career politician in a country that disdains the profession, a proponent of better government in an era defined by bipartisan suspicion of the state, and a practicing Jew in a nation that prefers presidents who are at least nominally Protestant. Mr. Shapiro has angered some Democrats by backing school vouchers and defending Israel, although he has criticized its current government. And Pennsylvania — while similar demographically to swing states like Michigan and Wisconsin — is less racially diverse than the United States as a whole, and in particular has a relatively small share of Latinos.

Perhaps his biggest challenge, certainly in pursuing the Democratic nomination, is simply that a lot of progressives don’t want a centrist. They see the party as defined and held together by its commitments to change; they believe it is those commitments that motivate people to vote for Democratic candidates. “Progress is our heritage,” Ted Kennedy declared in his 1980 speech conceding the party’s nomination to the centrist candidate, President Jimmy Carter. “What is right for us as Democrats is also the right way for Democrats to win.” For progressives, it is always 1980, always on the cusp of that fateful choice between integrity and tepid centrism.

Healthy political parties, however, cannot be solely progressive or conservative. They must be both. They necessarily embody a set of judgments about what to preserve and what to change. Democrats may prefer to describe themselves as “conservationists” committed to protecting the natural environment or “preservationists” opposed to development that disrupts established communities. But those are fundamentally conservative projects, devoted to protecting what already exists. Almost a century after Franklin Roosevelt created Social Security, it is no longer progressive to defend the program. It will soon be older than all of its beneficiaries.

The first great exponent of modern conservatism, the Anglo-Irish politician Edmund Burke, would have had no trouble recognizing Mr. Trump’s Republican Party as embodying the political tendencies he regarded as most dangerous. Burke, writing during the French Revolution, saw conservatism as a bulwark against radicalism, a defense of society against the ravages of men who had lost their moral compasses and were wielding power almost as an end in itself. He would have loathed Mr. Trump.

I think Burke also would have recognized Mr. Shapiro as something of a kindred spirit. Burke understood that change was necessary. States that lacked the capacity to change, he wrote, also lacked the capacity to survive. What he argued, however, was that societies should address problems by improving existing institutions rather than knocking them down.

When I put this to Mr. Shapiro, he was understandably reluctant to embrace “conservative” as a description of any part of his politics. “I do believe in the institutions,” he told me, “but they’ve got to be reformed so they can work for the people.”

Call it what you will: Mr. Shapiro’s challenge will be to persuade people that the best way to address our problems — the best way to make America great again — is to double down on the things that got us here in the first place. Not incidentally, these are also the things that voters routinely say they care about most.

We were the best educated nation in the world. We need to invest in education.

Our infrastructure was the envy of the world. We need to invest in infrastructure.

We ensured that prosperity was broadly distributed. We need to do that again.

In April, on the first night of Passover, a man named Cody Allen Balmer scaled the fence around the Pennsylvania governor’s mansion. He smashed windows and threw Molotov cocktails into the building, setting it ablaze. Mr. Shapiro, his family and some guests were home at the time but escaped without injuries.

Mr. Shapiro talked about the attack in a speech he gave a few months later, at the Eradicate Hate Global Summit. He said a lot of familiar things, but also something that was less familiar. He said that people, especially younger Americans, are not getting what they need from the government, and that is part of the reason some of them conclude that violence is the only path forward. Referring to his administration’s work to streamline the process of applying for permits, he said, “I realize a permit won’t end violence, but maybe it causes someone to have a bit more faith that the system can work for them.”

“Think of it,” he said, “the one time someone turns to government for help — and gets it.”

There’s a becoming modesty in that thought. And a lot of stuff to get done.

articles.title: Cruelty, Bigotry and Rage. What’s Not to Like?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Kevin Roberts, president of the Heritage Foundation, attempted to defend Tucker Carlson and Nick Fuentes — a Holocaust denier and known Hitler sympathizer — by claiming they were 'close friends' and that cancel culture was a threat. However, this stance triggered a massive internal revolt, with staff resignations, the severing of ties by the National Task Force to Combat Antisemitism, and widespread criticism of the movement’s moral decline. The article argues that the Republican Party, under the influence of Donald Trump’s toxic legacy, has normalized extremism and lawlessness, allowing figures like Carlson and Fuentes to gain mainstream popularity. Despite efforts by some conservatives to uphold moral standards, these voices are marginalized or dismissed as 'leftist' or 'sanctimonious'. The article warns that without a fundamental recommitment to decency, the movement risks being handed over to figures who continue Trump’s legacy of cruelty, bigotry, and rage.
keyTakeAways: Kevin Roberts, president of the Heritage Foundation, defended Tucker Carlson and Nick Fuentes in a video released on October 30, 2025, claiming they were 'close friends' of the foundation and criticizing 'cancel culture'.
The defense failed to quell internal dissent, resulting in a staff revolt, resignations of senior employees, and the severing of ties by the National Task Force to Combat Antisemitism.

Nick Fuentes, a Holocaust denier and known fan of Adolf Hitler, was featured in a controversial interview with Tucker Carlson, which went viral and gained over 18 million views on X and 5.6 million on YouTube.
Tucker Carlson's podcast and media presence remain dominant, with the Fuentes interview becoming one of his top-viewed videos, surpassing even his prime-time Fox News show in reach.
The conservative movement has undergone a shift in which fringe figures like Fuentes and Carlson have gained mainstream popularity, undermining traditional moral standards.
Prominent right-wing figures such as Sean Davis of The Federalist have criticized those who oppose Carlson and Fuentes, labeling such criticism as 'leftist' or 'sanctimonious'.

The article argues that the Republican Party's internal culture has been poisoned by Trump-era toxic norms, leading to the marginalization of decent, accountable conservatives like Mitt Romney, Liz Cheney, and Adam Kinzinger.
The movement is now in crisis as many conservatives begin to question its descent into cruelty, bigotry, and rage, but the influence of Carlson and Fuentes remains too powerful to contain.
The article warns that without a recommitment to moral standards, the Republican Party risks being handed over to a successor like Carlson, who continues Trump’s legacy of antisemitism and extremism.

articles.content:
# Cruelty, Bigotry and Rage. What’s Not to Like?

Published: 2025-11-09T06:00:15-05:00

Kevin Roberts, the president of the Heritage Foundation, must be confused.

Last month, he turned to the most reliable move in the Republican crisis-management playbook, and it didn’t work. On Oct. 30, three days after his friend Tucker Carlson released a softball interview with Nick Fuentes, a Holocaust denier and perhaps the most notorious fan of Adolf Hitler in American public life, Roberts posted a video online that decried cancel culture.

“We will always defend truth,” Roberts said. “We will always defend America, and we will always defend our friends against the slander of bad actors who serve someone else’s agenda.”

“That includes Tucker Carlson,” Roberts continued, “who remains — and as I have said before — always will be a close friend of the Heritage Foundation. The venomous coalition attacking him are sowing division. Their attempt to cancel him will fail.”

It’s hard to overstate how much this approach tends to work in the modern Republican Party. The hatred of the left — and of conservatives who are critical of Donald Trump — is so overwhelming that even the most basic acts of moral hygiene are considered weak or woke, or worse.

Even if you are uncomfortable with the words or actions of your fellow Republicans, there is relentless pressure to swallow your tongue. There should be no enemies to your right. The left is the true existential threat to the United States.

When Roberts, who was also a guiding force of Project 2025, recorded his video, he could be forgiven for thinking that neither Carlson nor Fuentes was particularly toxic on the right. After all, Carlson spoke at the 2024 Republican National Convention and at Charlie Kirk’s memorial service, and he hosts one of the top rated podcasts in the nation.

Fuentes, for his part, dined with Trump at Mar-a-Lago along with Kanye West in 2022, and Marjorie Taylor Greene spoke at Fuentes’s America First Political Action Conference that same year.

But Roberts miscalculated. His statement tore the Heritage Foundation apart. Facing a staff revolt, he issued a new statement more clearly condemning Fuentes (but still leaving Carlson alone), and when that didn’t quell the uprising, he held an all-staff meeting that quickly degenerated into an airing of grievances, with some Heritage employees eviscerating Roberts and passionately condemning the moral decline of the conservative movement and others — often with equal emotion — standing by his side.

Roberts remains Heritage’s president and has vowed to stay, but senior foundation employees have resigned, the National Task Force to Combat Antisemitism has severed its ties with the group, and vast segments of the right are in open revolt against both Roberts and Carlson.

Readers might be a little bit stumped. Wait, this is what’s splitting the right? A podcast conversation? It’s not that dialogues like this don’t matter (they do), but after everything that America has seen and endured since 2015, why now?

The answer is rooted in part in the unstable bargain that millions of conservatives made with themselves and with America to keep supporting Trump.

First, as a bit of background, Trump’s rise not only eviscerated the idea that there should be any kind of character test for participation in Republican politics, it also resulted in an aggressive, vicious purge from the party and the movement of anyone who attempted to hold Trump accountable for depravity and lawlessness. Some of us have even been told that we’ve abandoned our Christian faith for opposing Trump.

Many of the conservatives who remained didn’t want to abandon the president, but they also didn’t want to completely abandon decency, either. So they chose a third way. Trump receives special dispensation (witness the much more muted response to Trump’s dinner with Fuentes, especially among Republican lawmakers), but standards still apply to everyone else. Other Republicans have to toe the line.

The most consequential example of Republicans refusing to hold Trump accountable is, of course, the second impeachment conviction vote in 2021. Mitch McConnell punted Trump’s political future to the Biden Department of Justice and Republican primary voters. We know how that worked out.

You could see this dynamic in play more recently in the response to the Trump administration’s about-face on releasing the Epstein files. There was immense fury on parts of the right, but much of it was directed at Pam Bondi, the attorney general, and not at Trump, the man who now calls the lingering Epstein scandal a “Democrat hoax.”

But this approach suffers from a fatal flaw. A movement, especially one that verges on an outright cult of personality, is defined by its leader, not by its rank and file. And when the leader is lawless and depraved, then efforts to contain his influence while preserving his power are doomed to fail.

The proof is everywhere. Throughout the Trump era, many of the most prominent voices of right-wing America have only become shriller, angrier and, yes, more racist and more antisemitic. The right-wing media universe is culturally different in 2015 than it was in 2025 — substantially so.

The balance of power has flipped upside down. The fringe has become mainstream, and the mainstream has become fringe.

And now, with the end of Trump’s presidency coming into view, there is an increasing number of conservatives who fear that the movement has been and is being completely redefined — not just in Trump’s image, but in Carlson’s and Fuentes’s as well. And now some of these conservatives are speaking up.

A great deal is riding on their ability to win this fight. Trump will not be president for a third term, and the question of who will represent the Republican Party in the years to come is of immeasurable importance.

I want to believe that a large number of conservatives are in the process of waking up. They’re finally questioning what their movement has become.

But I’m rather afraid that they’re too late. One sign that might be the case is that virtually every person who’s raised a voice against Carlson has a far smaller audience than he does. Since Carlson posted his interview with Fuentes less than two weeks ago on X, it has racked up almost 18 million views. On YouTube it has 5.6 million views.

In fact, the Fuentes interview is already Carlson’s fourth most popular video, despite being online for less than two weeks. (If you’re wondering, his most popular one is his friendly interview with the even more vile Vladimir Putin.) To put those numbers in context, they top the viewership of his prime-time Fox News show, when he was the top-rated cable television host in America.

Compounding the problem, there are many prominent right-wing influencers who won’t explicitly defend Carlson or Fuentes but will scold the people who are confronting them.

Sean Davis, the chief executive of The Federalist, for example, attacked Ben Shapiro after Shapiro condemned both Carlson and Fuentes, writing, “Not really sure I’m willing to be lectured on who is allowed to talk to who and why by someone yukking it up with Jake Tapper, one of the most corrupt, hateful, and dishonest left-wing-operatives-masquerading-as-a-journalist in all of media.”

Got that? We can’t condemn good old Tucker for elevating an actual fan of Hitler in front of many millions of people because that will distract from taking on the real enemy, Jake Tapper.

I’m tempted to just laugh about it, but the stakes are too high and Davis’s sentiments are too popular for me to face the future with anything but real alarm.

Making the problem worse, the fight for the future of the Republican Party is taking place only after many of its most thoughtful and decent members have been excommunicated. Millions upon millions of Republicans have been told that these brave men and women — Mitt Romney, Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger, to name just three — are traitors to the cause.

The Republican rank and file have also been conditioned to dismiss moral arguments against MAGA as sanctimonious and complaints about Republican racism and antisemitism as inherently leftist. Hearts are hardened, ears shut.

I don’t know if Roberts will survive at Heritage, but I do know that Carlson and Fuentes and their constellation of friends and allies are far too popular to cancel or even to contain.

The fight for the future of the Republican Party is underway, but until the demand for decency reaches toward the very top of the movement, then Trump’s malignant influence will continue to metastasize, and he’ll hand the baton to a woman or a man (including, possibly, Carlson himself) who extends Trump’s legacy of cruelty, bigotry and rage.

# Philippines Braces for Enormous Typhoon, Still Reeling From the Last

Published: 2025-11-09T09:57:59-05:00

Troops mobilized alongside emergency workers as the biggest typhoon this year to threaten the Philippines — Typhoon Fung-wong — barreled toward the eastern seaboard on Sunday, less than a week after another storm left more than 200 people dead.

At 9:10 p.m. local time Sunday, Super Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall over Dinalungan, Aurora Province, the government’s weather bureau said. As it approached the Philippines, the storm had maximum sustained winds of 115 miles per hour, the equivalent to a Category 3 hurricane, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center in Hawaii.

See the likely path and wind arrival times for Fung-wong

With an expected rain band of 1,600 kilometers, or nearly 1,000 miles, Fung-wong, known as Uwan locally, was expected to dump heavy rain over a large swath of the archipelago, the weather bureau said, including the main island of Luzon, the nation’s commercial and political hub.

More than one million people across 12 regions were pre-emptively evacuated ahead of the typhoon’s landfall, according to the Office of Civil Defense. The government also ordered the suspension of all classes in metropolitan Manila, a sprawling metropolis of nearly 15 million people, until Tuesday.

The effects of the storm were already being felt on Sunday. At least two deaths were reported — one from falling debris in Samar Province and the other from drowning in Catanduanes, according to the local authorities.

articles.title: Banning Social Media
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores growing global concern over the impact of social media on youth mental health, highlighting incidents of bullying, sextortion, and self-harm. It examines responses from governments and institutions, including Australia’s proposed ban on social media for teenagers under 16, which aims to enforce age restrictions and deactivate existing accounts. Meanwhile, Britain and California have implemented privacy-focused regulations instead of outright bans. Research shows such bans do not significantly improve student well-being, and experts like Julia Powles argue that the root issue lies in platform design and monetization models, not access. The article concludes that blanket bans may only treat symptoms, failing to address systemic manipulation in social media apps driven by advertising revenue, while also risking the loss of important social and educational benefits from platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube.
keyTakeAways: Social media platforms have been linked to serious issues among teens, including bullying, sextortion, body-shaming, self-harm, and unhealthy relationships with AI chatbots.
Australia is implementing a sweeping ban on social media for teenagers under 16, requiring platforms to deactivate over one million existing youth accounts.

The ban aims to address unenforced age restrictions that have allowed children under 13 to create accounts, but critics argue it fails to fix root causes such as manipulative design features and ad-driven monetization.
Alternatives like the UK’s focus on privacy controls and data restrictions show a more nuanced approach than outright bans.
Research from the University of Birmingham suggests that cellphone bans in schools do not significantly improve students’ mental well-being.
Experts like Julia Powles argue that social media bans treat symptoms rather than addressing the core issue — the financial incentives driving manipulative platform designs.
The broader issue is not just access but the design of platforms, which use attention-hacking techniques to keep users engaged and generate revenue through advertising.
UNICEF Australia warns that such bans may remove social media’s educational and social benefits, such as maintaining friendships and staying connected.

articles.content:
# Banning Social Media

Published: 2025-11-09T07:58:49-05:00

Bullying. Sextortion. Body-shaming. Self-harm. Viral student-fight videos. Never-ending newsfeeds. Unhealthy relationships with A.I. chatbots. Teenagers who can’t seem to put down their phones.

Parents and teachers are understandably concerned about social media. For all of the community, creativity and just plain fun kids enjoy online, hazards remain all too frequent, some children’s advocates say.

Over the past few years, as public concern over youth mental health has mounted, government and education leaders have been searching for ways to reduce online risks. Lawmakers have rushed to curb young people’s access to social networks. Schools have banned phones. Instagram, TikTok and Snap have introduced new teen safeguards. Now, Australia is poised to go even further with a sweeping social media ban for teenagers.

Can these bans actually help? Below, I explain what we know so far.

Young people regularly report having bad experiences with social media.

In 2021, a former Facebook employee warned executives, including Mark Zuckerberg, that a company survey found more than 20 percent of 13- to 15-year-olds said they had been bullied on Instagram — just within the previous week. Many of the teens surveyed, the former employee noted, also reported receiving “unwanted advances.”

Instagram has since bolstered safeguards for teens, including some intended to stop adult strangers from directly messaging teenagers who don’t follow them. Last year, Instagram also introduced a new safeguard to automatically blur nude images in direct messages sent to teenagers under 18.

But researchers and government officials have found flaws in some of the safeguards. Last year, New Mexico arrested three men who were accused of targeting children for sex, the state’s attorney general said, alleging that the men solicited state investigators who had posed as children on fake Instagram and Facebook accounts.

Some lawmakers and schools are resorting to tech bans.

One of the most sweeping is in Australia, where the government is trying to keep most kids off social media. Starting in December, the country will require platforms like Instagram, TikTok and YouTube to take “reasonable steps” to prevent Australians under the age of 16 from having accounts. As my colleague Victoria Kim in Sydney has reported, the country also wants social apps to deactivate existing accounts belonging to more than one million young Australians.

The Australian ban could address a vexing problem. Regulators complain that social networks have enabled millions of young children under the age of 13 to sign up for accounts, without sufficiently enforcing the companies’ own age restrictions. But the ban could affect social media benefits like friendships, UNICEF Australia has said, without fixing the problems young people face online. “Social media has a lot of good things, like education and staying in touch with friends,” the organization said in a statement on its website.

Britain has taken a different approach — by promoting increased privacy and time management controls, rather than banishing young people from apps. In 2020, Britain began prohibiting services like social networks and video game apps from using “nudging techniques” to steer young people to give up more data. Online services must also turn on the highest privacy settings by default for kids under 18. In 2022, California enacted a similar law. But a lawsuit by NetChoice, an industry trade group, has halted it, at least for now.

Schools are also trying to curb tech distractions. Today, 40 percent of countries bar or restrict student cellphone use, as do more than 30 U.S. states and the District of Columbia.

We have limited research on whether the bans work. After surveying more than 1,200 students in 30 schools across England, researchers at the University of Birmingham recently reported that cellphone bans did not improve students’ mental well-being.

Blanket tech bans can be crude instruments. They may make it harder for many young people to have social media accounts. But they often don’t change the underlying app features that many parents are worried about.

Many popular apps use powerful attention-hacking techniques that can hook young people, said Julia Powles, an Australian researcher who is the executive director of the U.C.L.A. Institute for Technology, Law and Policy. This keeps users online longer, she notes, and makes the companies more money from advertising.

“The root cause is the monetary incentive that drives these platforms,” Powles said. “It creates manipulative practices,” she added, “and it can be exploited by harmful industries like gambling and unhealthy food.”

Lawmakers may be missing the point, she said. Australia’s new social media ban, she noted, instructs companies to “disregard” the ads they run as well as ad revenue.

If she is right, the tech bans may be treating the symptoms — while doing little to tackle the root causes of the online risks for kids and teens.

New delays and disruptions to food-stamp benefits affected millions of low-income families. The most-clicked story in The Morning yesterday was about the Supreme Court letting the Trump administration temporarily withhold funding for those benefits.

What’s next for the Democratic Party? In Maine, Michigan and other states, primary candidates will choose between a center-left and a left-wing vision.

Far-right influencers have been pushing charges of a grand conspiracy against President Trump’s adversaries. Their case, whose theory is unsupported by evidence, is finally taking shape.

Someone fired shots at Border Patrol agents in Chicago, an official said, the latest in a series of clashes during an immigration crackdown that has lasted two months. No agents were injured.

Yacht owners are younger and wealthier than they were a decade ago. And they’re increasingly American, enriched by a roaring stock market and deep tax cuts.

The Trump administration is handing out hundreds of billions of dollars in tax breaks to some of the country’s most profitable companies and wealthiest investors.

The Justice Department opened an investigation into possible collusion among big meatpacking companies. The effort may mollify ranchers, who complain of rising beef prices.

The Times interviewed 40 men deported by the U.S. to a prison in El Salvador. They say they were shackled, beaten and sexually assaulted.

Trump insists that U.S. strikes “obliterated” Iran’s nuclear program this summer. But regional officials have become less convinced in the months since and now fear another war between Israel and Iran.

China is on a scientifically shaky mission to conquer aging. That includes longevity labs, “immortality islands” and grapeseed pills.

Hurricane Melissa ravaged Jamaica’s power grid. But people with rooftop solar panels, increasingly popular on the island, got their power back almost immediately.

Kim Kardashian and Joe Rogan want to know whether an interstellar object was sent by aliens. Almost all astronomers say it’s just a comet.

Psychologists consider chatbots the future of therapy. The F.D.A. is exploring whether to regulate them. Are they safe?

Should Democrats’ path to the 2026 midterms be progressive or moderate?

Moderate. Moving to the left will only continue to alienate working-class Democrats, who decidedly prefer capitalism to socialism. “In politics, as in life, moderation is key,” Douglas Schoen and Carly Cooperman write for The Hill.

Progressive. Centrism has allowed the Democratic Party to appear listless, unprincipled and beholden to the ultrawealthy; Mamdani’s politics are the opposite. “This, too, might scare the Democratic establishment: not because Mamdani could fail, but because he could succeed,” The Guardian’s Moira Donegan writes.

A.I. is on its way to becoming conscious. But that doesn’t mean it deserves our moral consideration, Barbara Gail Montero argues.

Here are columns by M. Gessen on gender and passports and Nicholas Kristof on Trump’s aid cuts to Nigeria.

Countless cracks: The Blue Mosque in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, shed turquoise, indigo and lapis tiles in a strong earthquake last week. But, like Afghanistan, it has endured for centuries.

“Wow factor”: Couples are adding live saxophones to their wedding receptions. Some guests can’t stand the sound. (If that’s you, these five minutes of sax might change your mind.)

DNA discoverer: James Watson decoded the blueprint for life with Francis Crick, making him one of the most important scientists of the 20th century. He wrote a celebrated memoir and later ignited an uproar with racist views. He died at 97.

N.F.L.: The Washington Commanders could name a new team stadium after Trump. The president plans to attend the Commanders’ game against the Detroit Lions today.

Sports business: YouTube TV will offer a $20 credit to subscribers if it cannot negotiate a new deal with ESPN/Disney networks.

By Elisabeth Egan

“Finding My Way,” by Malala Yousafzai: Yousafzai became a household name at 15, when she was shot by the Taliban for speaking out against its brutal regime in Pakistan. “She gave an indelible speech at the United Nations, wrote a best-selling memoir, became the youngest-ever winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and transitioned into a kind of living sainthood, all before finishing high school,” Reggie Ugwu wrote in a recent profile. In her new memoir, Yousafzai, now 28, tells a different story — a human, refreshingly down-to-earth one about her struggles to fit in during college and her determination to forge her own path, separate from the one prescribed for her when she was a teenager.

For more: The winner of the Booker Prize will be announced in London tomorrow. Which novel should win? Have your say.

By David Marchese

This week’s subject for The Interview is the pugnacious Fox News star Greg Gutfeld. His show, “Gutfeld!,” has firmly established its dominance in late night, drawing a significantly bigger audience than those of Jimmy Kimmel, Jimmy Fallon and Stephen Colbert. We talked about hypocrisy, why Fox News wanted him to do this interview (against his own instincts) and his late-night rivals.

Do you see Kimmel, Colbert and Fallon as competition?

Not really.

You called Colbert a “smug loser” or something like that. And the one that stood out for me about Kimmel was: “If that man was any more full of [expletive], he’d be a colostomy bag.”

I have this thing called the hierarchy of smears, and that means if you call somebody a fascist who’s going to destroy the world, I can call you anything. I’m never going to call somebody fat because they’re fat. I’m going to call you fat if you called me Hitler. And the best part about that is it hurts them. It hurts them more than if they were to call me Hitler because they have to look in the mirror every day. I know I’m not Hitler. They know they’re fat.

[“Gutfeld!” panelist] Kat [Timpf] makes fun of me over this. “Greg, you’re trying to turn calling people fat into a heroic endeavor.” But again, stop calling me a Nazi or Hitler or a fascist, and I’ll lay off the physical stuff. But the physical stuff doesn’t come close to ascribing this moral evil to somebody that then generates animosity among people who might do something to you, who might come to your house. That’s what I think. Does that make sense?

I understand what you’re saying. That’s not the same as saying I think it makes sense.

I’ll take “I understand what you’re saying” as “making sense.”

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Jean-Philippe Pleau, a Quebec writer, has gained national attention for his memoir 'Rue Duplessis: My Little Darkness,' which offers a raw and emotional account of growing up in a working-class, church-dominated neighborhood in Drummondville. The book, rooted in the historical context of Quebec's 'Great Darkness' under Premier Maurice Duplessis, explores themes of class defectorism — the shame and guilt of leaving one’s roots for a more privileged life. While the memoir caused rifts with his parents and led to a defamation lawsuit from 12 family members, it also sparked a deep cultural conversation in Quebec, with many people recognizing themselves in the story. The play adaptation of the memoir at Jean Duceppe Theater revealed widespread emotional resonance, with attendees identifying as 'class defectors.' Despite the personal conflict, Pleau discovered that his parents still maintain emotional ties to Rue Duplessis, including regular visits by his father, indicating a complex, enduring relationship between identity, memory, and place.
keyTakeAways: Jean-Philippe Pleau's memoir, 'Rue Duplessis: My Little Darkness,' became a bestseller and sparked a cultural conversation in Quebec about class mobility, shame, and the trauma of moving from a working-class background to a more privileged intellectual life.
The memoir is described as autobiographical but functions as a memoir, detailing abuse, poverty, homophobia, and xenophobia in a working-class neighborhood shaped by the 'Great Darkness' era.
Pleau's experience of class defectorism — feeling ashamed of his origins while trying to ascend socially — resonates with readers across Quebec, especially those from similar backgrounds.
The book caused a rift with his parents and led to a lawsuit by 12 members of his extended family, highlighting the deep emotional and familial consequences of class-based self-identity.

The play adaptation of the book, performed at Jean Duceppe Theater, elicited strong emotional reactions, with many attendees identifying as 'class defectors,' showing the widespread relevance of the narrative.

Despite the conflict, Pleau’s parents still show emotional ties to Rue Duplessis: his father visits regularly, and they once tried to repurchase the house, indicating enduring emotional bonds and unresolved grief.

articles.content:
# A Quebec Writer Confronts His ‘Little Darkness’ as a Class Defector

Published: 2025-11-09T05:00:32-05:00

The writer was back home. But as he neared the intersection of a street lined with low-slung houses, his steps grew tentative. He remained fixed in the middle of the street, Rue Duplessis, unsure, it seemed, whether to go forward or turn back.

The writer, Jean-Philippe Pleau, had described in raw detail growing up on the working-class block — and leaving it and his hometown, Drummondville — for a new, intellectual life in Montreal. His book, “Rue Duplessis: My Little Darkness,” has become a surprising best seller and a cultural reckoning in Quebec as many saw themselves in his anguished retelling of abandoning his social class for a higher one.

The book, however, chilled Mr. Pleau’s relations with his parents, who still live in Drummondville. A dozen members of his extended family sued him for defamation. Mr. Pleau knew that people in Drummondville had told his parents they must be “very angry.”

And so, he nearly jumped when a woman called out his name on Rue Duplessis.

“Mr. Jean-Philippe Pleau,” said the woman, a neighborhood resident in her 30s, who had recognized him from news coverage.

“What?” he said, some trepidation in his voice. “Yes, hi.”

Mr. Pleau seemed relieved when the woman smiled and said she had yet to read the book. She was waiting for her mother to finish.

It was a clear autumn day in the small industrial city of Drummondville, the sun casting long shadows on the sidewalk-less Rue Duplessis. Mr. Pleau had driven 90 minutes from Montreal for an interview for this article on a Saturday morning after a busy week.

He had recorded an episode on the theme of “revolt” for his weekly radio program, “Thinking Out Loud,” on Radio-Canada, Canada’s French-language public broadcaster. And he had wrapped up a monthlong performance of a play based on his book at Jean Duceppe, a major theater in Montreal.

Mr. Pleau, who had never been onstage before, played himself: a radio host narrating his own story. One evening, the audience — mostly French Québécois in their 60s and older — responded often with knowing laughter.

“It’s as if I were telling the story of people who were in their 70s and 80s while I’m 48 years old,” Mr. Pleau said.

His parents, now in their mid-70s, belonged to a generation born before the Quiet Revolution, the social upheaval that gave birth to today’s Quebec. Until the 1960s, French Québécois, or French Canadians, as they were called, were second-class citizens, even though they far outnumbered the English-speaking minority.

In the 1940s and 1950s, Quebec’s longtime political leader, Maurice Duplessis — the “Duplessis” of Mr. Pleau’s street — ran a repressive, populist and corrupt government that silenced dissent. A French Canadian, he controlled Quebec society in an alliance with the Roman Catholic Church, which ran the province’s schools with an emphasis on faith. The Duplessis era is known as “the Great Darkness.”

His death, in 1959, led to the Quiet Revolution: Quebec society became secular; education was loosened from the church’s grip and modernized; the arts and intellectual life flourished. French Canadians became economically powerful.

Mr. Pleau’s book focuses on the “little darkness” on Rue Duplessis, though, as the work’s reception suggested, its story could have taken place on countless other streets in Quebec. Published only in French, it is described as an autobiographical novel but is really a memoir.

Mr. Pleau writes of his life as the only child of an illiterate father and a mother with little education, both products of church-led schools. After his father lost his job as a sign maker, his parents ran a day care in their basement. The cash revenues went into a hiding spot to avoid paying taxes.

In a sweeping account extending to his grandparents and his extended family, Mr. Pleau describes abuse, alcoholism, racism, homophobia and xenophobia.

More than anything else, he depicts an oppressive cultural poverty that made his parents and many on Rue Duplessis incapable of imagining a different lot in life.

“When I was here as a child,” Mr. Pleau said, walking in the schoolyard of his old elementary school, “I never imagined myself doing radio.”

Yet Mr. Pleau was a sensitive and curious boy. Educated in the schools that emerged from the Quiet Revolution, he discovered sociology and the ways of the higher classes.

But this led to anguish, especially after moving to Montreal. When he landed at Radio-Canada — with its rich programming on culture and intellectual matters — he was confronted by the gulf between the class he was born into and the one he aspired to join. On the advice of his bosses at Radio-Canada, he took lessons for a year and a half to adjust his accent and diction. He hid, as best he could, gaps in his cultural literacy.

Ashamed of his origins, Mr. Pleau sought a clean break. He recalls cutting ties with a childhood friend from Rue Duplessis via email, in which he declared that he “was going to seek to become somebody else.”

Eventually, he came to terms with his past, in part from reading the French writers Annie Ernaux, the Nobel laureate, and Édouard Louis, whose works also explore the challenges of moving up socially. Though Quebec is less stratified than France, Mr. Pleau identified with those writers’ feelings of alienation, guilt and shame as “class defectors.”

A turning point came, he said, when he “began to feel ashamed of being ashamed.”

That insight resonated among the 30 people who came to meet him over a breakfast at the Duceppe theater. To a moderator’s question, about half said they had recognized themselves in Rue Duplessis, and a third identified themselves as “class defectors.”

“I felt I knew the book even before I read it,” said Francine Sylvestre, 67, one woman who spoke up. Ms. Sylvestre and her husband, André Hamelin, 71, said in an interview later that Rue Duplessis had fueled intense conversations within their extended families.

A man came to congratulate Ms. Sylvestre on her public comment.

“We all went through the same thing,” he said. “I almost spoke up, but I was too shy.”

A woman asked Mr. Pleau about the state of his relations with his parents after the book’s publication last year, and the subsequent lawsuit, which is continuing.

The play starts with several messages that Mr. Pleau leaves on his parents’ answering machine after publication — messages that go unanswered.

Mr. Pleau said he had recently had a three-hour dinner with his parents to clear the air. His parents, who have not spoken out in public and could not be reached for comment, did not see the play, Mr. Pleau said.

In front of the parish church he had attended into his late teens — years of dwindling membership finally shuttered it in 2020 — he recalled how his father had stopped believing but kept going to church “just in case.”

As he strolled down Rue Duplessis, Mr. Pleau said he did not know what his parents, who sold the family house about 15 years ago, felt about the street.

As he approached his old home, a semidetached bungalow with two cars parked under an awning in the driveway, Mr. Pleau stumbled on a clue. The current owner, Lyne Coté, a nurse, recognized him and invited him into the backyard. Her husband, a truck driver, was sleeping inside after an overnight shift.

Ms. Coté said she had often taken mail to his parents at the apartment where they now lived. She informed him — to his surprise — that his parents had even tried to repurchase the house. And that wasn’t all.

His father, Ms. Coté told him, still came to Rue Duplessis several times a week in his white Toyota.

“He drives by, then slows down,” she said. “Really slows down.”

“You serious?” Mr. Pleau said. Then, with tears welling up in his eyes, he added, “I didn’t know.”

“Come again, no problem,” she told him. “Bring your dad and mom.”

# Blue Origin to Launch NASA’s ESCAPADE Mission to Mars: How to Watch

Published: 2025-11-09T10:27:44-05:00

New Glenn, the powerful orbital rocket built by Blue Origin, the space company founded by Jeff Bezos, is on a launchpad in Florida. It is ready for its second mission.

Tucked inside the rocket is NASA’s ESCAPADE mission — two identical spacecraft that will orbit Mars to measure the dynamics of that planet’s magnetic field and atmosphere.

But that is only one goal for the launch. Blue Origin will attempt to land the rocket’s booster stage on a floating platform in the Atlantic, a feat that only Elon Musk’s company, SpaceX, has so far achieved.

Liftoff from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida is scheduled for Sunday afternoon during an 88-minute launch window that begins at 2:45 p.m. Eastern time and ends at 4:13 p.m.

Blue Origin will provide online coverage of the launch starting 45 minutes before liftoff.

If the launch is delayed by weather or a technical glitch, it may be grounded indefinitely. In an attempt to relieve congestion in the nation’s airspace during the ongoing federal government shutdown, the Federal Aviation Administration announced that, beginning on Monday, no commercial rockets can lift off between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. local time.

Blue Origin officials said they were talking with the F.A.A. to see if they could obtain an exception if Sunday’s launch attempt were to be called off.

At 321 feet tall, New Glenn is a giant. It is taller than the Falcon 9 rockets regularly flown by SpaceX, but shorter than the Starship vehicle the company is testing in Texas.

The rocket is named after John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth.

Its payload nose cone, at seven meters wide, offers at least twice as much space for payloads as other rockets currently in operation.

The booster stage — the lower part of the rocket that lifts off the ground and carries the upper stage through the densest part of the atmosphere — is designed to land and to be reused.

After it propels the rocket up through the dense, lower part of the atmosphere, the giant New Glenn booster stage will drop away and try to set down on a floating platform named Jacklyn, after Mr. Bezos’ mother.

That boat is already positioned about 375 miles off the coast in the Atlantic Ocean.

Yes, SpaceX regularly recovers the booster stages of its Falcon 9 rockets, then reflies them, a feat it first accomplished a decade ago. Since then, SpaceX has successfully landed the boosters more than 500 times. One of its boosters has flown 31 times.

No other company has landed a stage of an orbital-class rocket. Blue Origin does land and reuse the boosters of its much smaller New Shepard rockets, which send tourists and science experiments on up-and-down, suborbital flights to the edge of space, but not to orbit. Reusing the booster stage of New Glenn will be key to speeding the pace of launches if Blue Origin is to become a serious competitor to SpaceX.

In the near future, a Chinese company, Landspace, is also aiming to land the booster of its new Zhuque-3 rocket, which, at first glance, looks like a clone of the Falcon 9.

This rocket is carrying ESCAPADE, or Escape and Plasma Acceleration Dynamics Explorers, a NASA-financed mission developed by the Space Sciences Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley. The mission consists of two identical spacecraft named Blue and Gold — the school colors of Berkeley.

The two spacecraft will take a long, slow trip to Mars, arriving in September 2027. After they reach their destination, Blue and Gold will spend at least a year orbiting the red planet to take measurements of the magnetic field around it, as well as the dance of charged particles in the thin atmosphere.

The rocket is also carrying a NASA communications technology demonstration from the company Viasat.

ESCAPADE was originally scheduled to launch on the first New Glenn mission in October 2024. However, when it appeared that New Glenn would not be ready in time, NASA decided to pull the mission off that flight and put the spacecraft into storage.

The first New Glenn finally launched in January, and its primary mission was a success. The payload — a demonstration of Blue Ring, a technology that Blue Origin is developing to move payloads around in space — made it to orbit and successfully completed its tests.

But the secondary goal of landing the booster was not successful. The booster’s engines failed to reignite as it re-entered the atmosphere, and it crashed into the Atlantic instead of landing on the Jacklyn floating platform.
